questions.text: Among women aged 18 to 34 years in a community, height is normally distributed with a mean of 158 cm and a standard deviation of 3cm. what percentage of women will have a height between 155-161 cm?
questions.solution:
To solve this problem, we need to determine the percentage of women whose height falls between 155 cm and 161 cm, given that the heights are normally distributed with a mean of 158 cm and a standard deviation of 3 cm.


  1. Interpret the Z-scores:

A Z-score of -1 corresponds to one standard deviation below the mean, and a Z-score of 1 corresponds to one standard deviation above the mean.

  1. Determine the percentage:

The percentage of data within one standard deviation of the mean (between Z = -1 and Z = 1) in a normal distribution is approximately 68%.

Therefore, the correct answer is b. 68%

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The percentage of data within one standard deviation of the mean (between Z = -1 and Z = 1) in a normal distribution is approximately 68%.

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-05, Page Number -101-105.

questions.text: In an epidemiological study null hypothesis came out to be false and rejected. However, in reality, null hypothesis was true. Type of error:
questions.solution:
In epidemiological studies, errors related to hypothesis testing are classified into two main types:

  • Type 1 Error (False Positive): Occurs when the null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected when it is actually true. This means the study suggests an effect or association exists when it does not.
  • Type 2 Error (False Negative): Occurs when the null hypothesis is not rejected when it is actually false. This means the study fails to detect an effect or association that does exist.

Given the situation where the null hypothesis was rejected, but in reality, it was true, this corresponds to a Type 1 Error.

So, the correct answer is: A. Type 1


KEY TAKEAWAYS-In the context of rejecting a true null hypothesis, the relevant error is Type 1 Error.

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-09, Page Number -168-174.

questions.text:
What are the Functions of a male health worker posted under health department, covering population of 5000:
A. Accompany pregnant female to hospital
B. Immunization of children as per schedule
C. IUCD insertion
D. Malaria slide preparation
questions.solution:
In the context of a male health worker posted under the health department, covering a population of 5,000, the following functions are typically part of their responsibilities:

  • A. Accompany pregnant female to hospital: Male health workers may assist in referring and ensuring that pregnant women receive timely care, but this is not their primary role.
  • B. Immunization of children as per schedule: This is a key responsibility, as male health workers are involved in ensuring that children receive their vaccinations according to the immunization schedule.
  • C. IUCD insertion: Typically, IUCD insertion is performed by trained female health workers like ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives) or medical officers.
  • D. Malaria slide preparation: Male health workers are involved in preparing malaria slides for diagnosis, particularly in areas where malaria is prevalent.
  • Given this context, the correct answer is: B. -B & D

Here are the key functions that a male health worker typically performs in a community setting,


KEY TAKEAWAYS- A male health worker posted under health department, covering population of 5000 is concerned with immunization, health education, malaria slide preparation, etc.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-10, Page number: 705-710.

questions.text: : Height of a group of 50 boys aged 15 years was 140+/- 15 cm and of 20 girls aged 15 years was 135+/- 6 cm. The most appropriate test used to measure significance of the difference in height is :
questions.solution:
To measure the significance of the difference in height between two independent groups (boys and girls), the most appropriate test is the unpaired t-test (also known as the independent samples t-test.

This test compares the means of two independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them.

So, the correct answer is: B. Unpaired t test

Here is the information about usage of each statistical test:


KEY TAKEAWAYS- This test compares the means of two independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-09, Page Number -178-184.

questions.text: Which of the following demonstrates highest correlation between variables?
questions.solution:
The highest possible value for a correlation coefficient is +1.00 or -1.00, indicating a perfect correlation.

Correlation coefficients cannot exceed +1.00 or go below -1.00.

Given the options:

  • Option A (+2.00) is not possible since correlation values cannot exceed +1.00.
  • Option B (-0.75) shows a strong negative correlation.
  • Option C (+0.25) shows a weak positive correlation.
  • Option D (+0.50) shows a moderate positive correlation.

Therefore, Option b (-0.75) demonstrates the highest correlation (in magnitude) between the variables.

Additional Key Points:

  • Direction: The sign of the coefficient (positive or negative) indicates the direction of the relationship.
    • Positive Correlation (+): As one variable increases, the other also increases.
    • Negative Correlation (-): As one variable increases, the other decreases.
  • Magnitude: The absolute value of the correlation coefficient indicates the strength of the relationship.
    • Values close to +1 or -1 represent stronger relationships.
    • Values close to 0 represent weaker relationships.
  • Linear Relationship: The correlation coefficient only measures linear relationships; it does not capture non-linear patterns.


KEY TAKEAWAYS- The coefficient of correlation is a statistical measure that quantifies the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables. It is commonly represented by the symbol r. The value of the correlation coefficient ranges between -1 and 1, where:

  • r = 1: Perfect positive linear relationship (as one variable increases, the other increases).
  • r = -1: Perfect negative linear relationship (as one variable increases, the other decreases).
  • r = 0: No linear relationship between the variables

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-12, Page Number -226-230.

choices.text: It is a measure of spread, which is equal to the range
It is a measure of the mean values of the data
It is an appropriate measure of spread for skewed data
It is the root mean square deviation

questions.text: In a longitudinal study of a population of patients with diabetes, which one of the following describes the standard deviation of the HbA1c?
questions.solution:
Standard deviation is a statistical measure that quantifies the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values. Here are some key points about standard deviation:

Standard Deviation:

  • Definition:
    • It is the square root of the variance, which is the average of the squared differences between each data point and the mean.
  • Formula:

Interpretation:

  • Low Standard Deviation: Indicates that data points are close to the mean, showing less variability.
  • High Standard Deviation: Indicates that data points are spread out over a wider range, showing more variability.

Usefulness:

  • It provides insights into the spread of the data and helps in understanding the degree of consistency or variability within a dataset.
  • It can be used to compare the spread of data between different datasets or groups.
  • Option A: Standard deviation is not equal to the range; the range is the difference between the maximum and minimum values in the dataset.
  • Option B: Standard deviation is not a measure of the mean values of the data; it measures how much the data points deviate from the mean.
  • Option C: While standard deviation can be used with skewed data, it may not be the most appropriate measure of spread for highly skewed data, where other measures like the interquartile range (IQR) might be preferred.
  • Option D: This correctly describes standard deviation as the root mean square deviation from the mean, which is the most accurate characterization of what standard deviation represents.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Standard deviation is a measure of the spread or dispersion of a set of data points around the mean. It is calculated as the square root of the variance, which is the average of the squared differences between each data point and the mean.

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-03, Page Number - 46-52.

questions.text: An investigator of covid surveillance team collecting blood sample from every 5th house for sero -surveillance study. Type of sampling?
questions.solution:
The type of sampling described, where blood samples are collected from every 5th house, is: Systematic random

  • Option B: Systematic Random Sampling: This method involves selecting samples at regular intervals from a list or sequence. In this case, every 5th house is selected for the sero-surveillance study, which fits the definition of systematic sampling.
  • Option A: Simple Random Sampling : Every house would have an equal chance of being selected, but this method does not involve a systematic interval like selecting every 5th house.
  • Option C: Stratified Random Sampling : The population is divided into subgroups (strata), and samples are randomly taken from each stratum. This approach is not described in the scenario.
  • Option D: Non-Random Sampling :This refers to sampling methods where not every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected, which is not the case here since every 5th house is systematically chosen.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Selecting every Nth member from a list or sequence from a random set is systematic random sampling.

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-06, Page Number -116-120.

questions.text: Sub centers are very important centers to provide health services. They cover a population of 5000 in plain area. Most important worker of sub -center is MPW- m/f .MPW- f is mainly responsible for all types of MCH care. All can be performed at sub center for pregnant women except?
questions.solution:
At a sub-center, which provides various maternal and child health (MCH) services, all activities for pregnant women can be performed except:

Ultrasonography requires specialized equipment and trained personnel, which are typically not available at sub-centers.

These centers focus on basic maternal care, such as weight recording, hemoglobin testing, and antenatal services, but ultrasound services are usually provided at higher-level healthcare facilities like primary health centers (PHCs) or hospitals.

Activities performed at a sub-center:


Reference: IAPSM Textbook of Community Medicine, 2nd Edition,chapter-39, Page number: 775-782.

questions.text: Best indication of socio-economic status of a country:
questions.solution:
The best indicator of the socio-economic status of a country is typically:

IMR (Infant Mortality Rate)

The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is a sensitive indicator because it reflects multiple factors, including maternal health, quality of healthcare, access to medical services, nutrition, sanitation, and overall living conditions. It is often used as a key measure to assess the socio-economic development of a country.

Other options:

  • MMR (Maternal Mortality Rate) also indicates healthcare quality but is more specific to maternal health.
  • Crude Death Rate provides a general overview but is less sensitive to socio-economic factors.
  • TFR (Total Fertility Rate) reflects population growth trends but is less directly linked to socio-economic status than IMR.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- IMR is widely regarded as the most comprehensive indicator of a country's socio-economic status, as it encompasses various social, health, and economic conditions affecting the population.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-09, Page number:612-618.

questions.text: During corona pandemic government is analyzing money spent on corona vaccine trial and its production cost over life saved due to corona infection . Management technique is?
questions.solution:
The management technique being used to analyse the cost of corona vaccine trials and production in relation to the lives saved and the improvement in the national economy.

Cost-effectiveness refers to a measure of the economic efficiency of an intervention, project, or policy.

Unlike Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA), which assigns monetary values to both costs and benefits, Cost-Effectiveness Analysis (CEA) compares the relative costs of different strategies or interventions with the outcomes achieved, usually expressed in non-monetary terms such as health improvements, lives saved, or environmental impact reduced.

CEA is particularly common in healthcare, public policy, and environmental management, where outcomes cannot be easily quantified in monetary terms.

Incorrect Options:

  • Cost-Benefit Analysis (b)- Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA), assigns monetary values to both costs and benefits
  • System Analysis (c): This involves examining and improving systems or processes, not specifically about evaluating costs versus benefits.
  • Network Analysis (d): This technique is used for planning and managing complex projects with interdependent tasks, not for cost versus benefit evaluation.

Therefore, Cost-Effective Analysis is the most appropriate technique for this evaluation.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Cost-effectiveness refers to a measure of the economic efficiency of an intervention, project, or policy

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-23, Page number:1002-1008.

questions.text: Most essential fatty acid which serves as a basis for production of other essential fatty acids (EFA) in the body is?
questions.solution:
The most essential fatty acid that serves as a basis for the production of other essential fatty acids in the body is: C. Linoleic acid

Linoleic acid is an omega-6 fatty acid and is essential because the human body cannot synthesize it, but it can convert it into other important fatty acids such as arachidonic acid.

Essential fatty acids (EFAs):

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Linoleic acid (LA) and Alpha-Linolenic acid (ALA) are the two primary EFAs because the body cannot synthesize them. They serve as the precursors for other fatty acids like arachidonic acid (AA), eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-11,Page number:736-740.

questions.text: Richest source of protein (percent content) is?
questions.solution:
The richest source of protein in terms of percentage content is:B. Soybean

Soybean contains approximately 36-40% protein, making it the richest source of protein among the options provided. Chicken' egg, Lentils (dry) and mutton have lower protein content by percentage, though they are still considered good sources of high-quality protein.

Protein content from various sources in terms of percentage:

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Among these, soybean stands out as one of the richest plant-based sources of protein, while animal sources such as chicken breast, mutton, and fish also provide high protein content.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-11,Page number.: 748-754.

questions.text: The highest percentage of monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) is present in?
questions.solution:
The highest percentage of monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) is present in: Groundnut oil

Groundnut oil (also known as peanut oil) is rich in monounsaturated fatty acids, particularly oleic acid, making it a top source of MUFA among the options listed

Percentage of monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) in various oils:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Olive oil and avocado oil have some of the highest MUFA content, while oils like groundnut oil and canola oil are also rich in MUFA.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-11,Page number:736-740.

choices.text: It is a product of biological value and digestibility coefficient divided
It is the proportion of ingested protein that is retained in the body
It is the grams of protein required for gain in 1 g of body protein
Egg protein is called reference protein as it has the highest NPU

questions.text: Following are correct about Net Protein Utilization (NPU) EXCEPT
questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about Net Protein Utilization (NPU) is:C. It is the grams of protein required for gain in 1 g of body protein

This statement does not describe NPU.

The NPU is a measure of the proportion of ingested protein that is retained in the body after digestion and absorption, reflecting both the protein's biological value (BV) and digestibility.

Correct Explanation for the Other Options:

  • A. NPU is indeed a product of biological value (BV) and digestibility coefficient.
  • B. NPU measures the proportion of ingested protein that is retained and used by the body.
  • D. Egg protein is considered the reference protein because it has a very high NPU.

Key facts about Net Protein Utilization (NPU):

KEY TAKEAWAYS- NPU is a crucial metric for evaluating how efficiently the body can utilize different types of dietary proteins for growth and maintenance.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-11,Page number.:744-748.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of quantitative research?
questions.solution:
The characteristic of quantitative research is:B. Structured data collection

Quantitative research involves the collection and analysis of numerical data, and it often uses structured methods such as surveys, experiments, and statistical analyses to ensure consistency and reliability in the data collected.

Characteristics of quantitative research:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Quantitative research is characterized by its emphasis on numerical data, objectivity, and statistical analysis to draw conclusions and make generalizations.

Reference: IAPSM Textbook of Community Medicine, 2nd Edition,chapter- 44,Page number.:844-848.
